No policy changes. Current situation in more detail:    •	Broad restrictions on non-essential travel from many countries outside the European Union, including the United States, remain in place. The French government has defined essential travel as entry by French citizens, residents of France, all foreign (including United States citizen) students (with appropriate visa or residence permit), and spouses and children of French citizens.  •	In rare cases, the French government will consider allowing travel in humanitarian situations and in cases of business activity important to the French economy, and have announced a program to allow unmarried couples to reunite.    https://archive.vn/jGRh1#selection-2331.0-2331.47    •	France announced they would be restricting travel from the UK from 00:00 (CET) on 20 December. Travel restriction apply to all air, car, ferry and train passengers. If you are due to travel to France please contact your travel operator. Until at least 6 January, only the following categories of people will be authorised to travel to France from the UK:  1.	French nationals and nationals of the European Area and their spouses and children  2.	British and/or third country nationals who are either habitually resident in France, the European Union or the European Area, or who must travel for certain essential reasons (as specified by the French government)  3.	British or third country nationals travelling for certain exceptional reasons, see the French Embassy London’s list.  •	All travellers from the UK, including children aged 11 and above, will need to present a negative COVID-19 test result, carried out less than 72 hours before departure  •	Please check our COVID-19 advice on things to consider, and be prepared to stay overseas longer than planned  •	Although there is no restriction on travel from most European countries, travel from most non-European countries is subject to entry restrictions  •	Arrivals from the UK will need to complete both a ‘sworn statement’ (déclaration sur l’honneur) form self-certifying they are not suffering from symptoms associated with coronavirus and have not been in contact with confirmed cases in the preceding fortnight, and a signed ‘travel certificate’ (attestation), confirming their reason for travel. These can be found on the French government’s website.    https://archive.vn/3mbzC

La capacité de dépistage dans les établissements scolaires sera également augmentée, avec un objectif de 300 000 tests par semaine et des objectifs fixés par académie.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115103746/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Testing freely available for asymptomatic people who are at particular risk from the disease.  La vaccination est désormais ouverte à l’ensemble des personnes appartenant aux catégories suivantes :  •	Les personnes âgées de plus de 75 ans (à partir de lundi 18 janvier).  •	Les résidents volontaires en EHPAD et USLD, qui sont vaccinés directement dans les établissements.  •	Les personnes âgées séjournant dans les établissements de santé et en services de soins de suite et de réadaptation.  •	Les personnes âgées hébergées en résidences autonomie, résidences services et autres lieux de vie spécialisés, ainsi que dans les foyers de travailleurs migrants.  •	Les personnes en situation de handicap, vulnérables, hébergées en maisons d’accueil spécialisées et foyers d’accueils médicalisés.  •	Les professionnels de santé (et autres professionnels des établissements de santé et des établissements médico-sociaux intervenant auprès de personnes vulnérables), les aides à domicile intervenant auprès de personnes âgées et handicapées vulnérables et les sapeurs-pompiers, lorsqu’ils ont plus de 50 ans ou présentent une ou plusieurs des comorbidités suivantes :  o	L’obésité (IMC>30),  o	La BPCO et l’insuffisance respiratoire,  o	L’hypertension artérielle compliquée,  o	L’insuffisance cardiaque,  o	Le diabète (de type 1 et de type 2)  o	L’insuffisance rénale chronique,  o	Les cancers et maladies hématologiques malignes actifs et de moins de 3 ans  o	Le fait d’avoir une transplantation d’organe solide ou de cellules souches hématopoïétiques,  o	La trisomie 21.  •	Les personnes ayant une pathologie qui les expose à un très haut risque face à la Covid-19 disposant d’une ordonnance médicale pour se faire vacciner prioritairement.  Les patients particulièrement vulnérables à la Covid concernés sont les suivants :  o	atteints de cancer et de maladies hématologiques malignes en cours de traitement par chimiothérapie  o	atteints de maladies rénales chroniques sévères, dont les patients dialysés  o	transplantés d’organes solides  o	transplantés par allogreffe de cellules souches hématopoïétiques  o	atteints de poly-pathologies chroniques, selon le critère suivant : au moins deux insuffisances d’organes  o	atteints de certaines maladies rares (voire liste sur le site du ministère de la santé)  o	atteints de trisomie 21.  Si vous êtes concerné, vous pouvez vous faire vacciner dès à présent dans un des centres de vaccination ouverts.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115113356/https://www.sante.fr/centres-vaccination-covid.html    Testing for people who do not meet these criteria is also available, but at a cost of about EUR 70 to EUR 100. Which however is covered by French Health insurance (“Sécurité Sociale”). So e.g. a US citizen who is not covered by French Health insurance would have to pay for the treatment individually.  https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Further confirmation that testing without symptoms is available (need to get an appointment via a website), but people who do not meet the above mentioned criteria are not considered a priority (implying it may take longer for them to get an appointment).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115121550/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

PARIS (Reuters) - France will start its COVID-19 vaccination programme next Sunday, Health Minister Olivier Veran wrote on his Twitter feed.  https://archive.vn/HrrMw

As of Dec. 31, only 352 people had gotten at least one dose of the vaccine, versus 131,626 in Germany and 944,539 in the U.K., according to data cited by Le Parisien.  https://archive.vn/0E17Q    From 2nd January, people over 50 will begin to be vaccinated (which had previously been planned for February), to speed up the vaccination roll out.  https://archive.vn/R00XW

A, C:    The HAS (Haute Autorite de Sante = High Authority of Health) recommends first vaccinating the elderly in establishments, in particular EHPADs, as well as the staff working there when they are at risk of developing a severe form of COVID. This represents around 1 million people.    On January 5, 2020, Olivier Véran indicated that firefighters and home helpers over 50 years old will be able to benefit from the injection as priority personnel. "They are also professionals who are in contact with fragile people and who may have to work with the sick," said the minister to justify this decision.  https://archive.vn/a0Ju1

A, C:    Previously coded policy is still in place in this period. By now, 318.216 have been vaccinated, out of which 10% are residents of care homes. The remainder are caregivers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities, but also firefighters, home helpers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities.  https://archive.vn/J7Rwn    So some members of the following groups have started receiving vaccines:  A Key workers  C Elderly groups  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    The vaccines that are given are PfizerBiontech and Moderna.  BioNTech-Pfizer's vaccine was approved by the EMA and then by the European Commission on 22 December. On Wednesday 6 January 2021, the European Commission gave the green light to the Covid-19 vaccine developed by the American start-up Moderna, this decision was approved by the High Health Authority on Friday 8 January 2021. To date, two additional vaccines are being evaluated by the EMA following Phase III clinical trials: the AstraZeneca and Janssen laboratories.  https://archive.vn/dNmaS    In addition, from 18 January, people over the age of 75 will be able to get vaccinated as well as people with one of the five pathologies leading to a very high risk of serious form of the disease, regardless of their age.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210113222447/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins    Note that the government has faced a lot of criticism regarding a perceived slowness and overly bureaucratic approach in rolling out the vaccines.  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    France wants to immunize 1 million people by the end of January but at the current vaccination rate, it will reach that target in late February.  There is also widespread vaccine-scepticism.  https://archive.vn/trhlh    Polls suggest that less than 40% of the population here is planning to take the vaccine.   https://archive.vn/J7Rwn

England enters lockdown on Tuesday 5 January. All schools are closed, except for the children of essential workers, despite all students having attended school on Monday 4th.     Colleges, primary (reception onwards) and secondary schools will remain open for vulnerable children and the children of critical workers. All other children will learn remotely until February half term  Universities- Those students who are undertaking training and study for the specific courses should return to face to face learning as planned and be tested twice, upon arrival or self-isolate for ten days.    All 4 devolved nations now have schools closed, meaning this is a policy that applies generally across the UK now      https://web.archive.org/web/20210106100514/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/national-lockdown-stay-at-home

All devolved nations are under stay at home orders    Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020.      The new rules - which will be put down in law - mean Scots will only be allowed to leave home for essential purposes, such as shopping for food and medicine, exercise and caring responsibilities.    No limit is to be put on how many times people can go out to exercise, but outdoor meetings are to be limited to a maximum of two people from two households.      These rules will apply across the Scottish mainland until at least the end of January, and will be kept under review.    https://web.archive.org/web/20

The government has quietly introduced a loophole to its eviction ban that waters down protections for people who lost their jobs during the pandemic.    Ministers on Friday announced that they were extending the ban on bailiff evictions that has been in place since the first lockdown in March, covering most tenants for another six weeks.    But the announcement did not mention a key change snuck out in legislation that will for the first time give landlords the power to evict people for not paying their rent during lockdown.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210115172832/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/eviction-ban-loophole-substantial-arrears-six-months-b1784836.html

The Government of Georgia imposed movement restrictions in major cities between 9 PM and 5 AM. During the restricted time, public and private transportation (including walking) is not permitted, unless it is for an essential need. Also, there is in place a recommendation for people over the age of 70 to remain at home.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/PBxRe  and Prevention of Coronavirus Spread in Georgia (archive.fo)

With a few exceptions, Georgia remains closed to foreign travelers. The entry ban for foreign citizens applies to air, land, and sea borders, including foreign citizens who are legal residents of Georgia, or have been living and working in Georgia, or own property or business. Also, there are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/PBxRe

A:    Pfizer vaccine    December 27: the first vaccinations will be performed in the reference hospitals of Attica to frontline health workers(Attiko, Evangelismos, Sotiria, Thriasio, Asklipieio Voulas).      Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143553/https://eody.gov.gr/erotiseis-kai-apantiseis-schetika-me-ton-emvoliasmo-gia-ton-koronoio-sars-cov-2/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143655/https://news.gtp.gr/2020/12/21/greece-announces-when-general-population-will-receive-covid-19-vaccine/

A, B:    Vaccinations will take place based on priority groups.     December 30: Greek authorities expect to receive a larger vaccine batch from Pfizer – 83,850 doses.    – Following the vaccination of frontline healthcare workers and vulnerable groups that have priority, the vaccinations of the general population will begin some time during the second ten days of January 2021.     The vaccine for the coronavirus (Covid-19) is expected to be available to Greece’s general population in mid-January, according to General Secretary of Primary Health Care Mario Themistokleous.    Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143553/https://eody.gov.gr/erotiseis-kai-apantiseis-schetika-me-ton-emvoliasmo-gia-ton-koronoio-sars-cov-2/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143655/https://news.gtp.gr/2020/12/21/greece-announces-when-general-population-will-receive-covid-19-vaccine/

Policy update: continue to restrict non-mandatory arrivals to Croatia. On January 13, the new border rules for entry were announced (read more about them here). On January 15, the rules are further explained, and the biggest change is that travelers arriving in Croatia from the United Kingdom and the South African Republic need to have a negative PCR test AND they need to self-isolate for 14 days (or have their self-isolation shortened if they pay for another test, at least 7 days after they've entered Croatia), no matter what their citizenship is.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117124536/https://www.koronavirus.hr/recommendations-and-instructions-for-crossing-the-state-border/736  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117131401/https://www.total-croatia-news.com/travel/43707-croatia-corona-travel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117131726/https://www.total-croatia-news.com/travel/49647-new-border-rules-for-croatia

Some restrictions on entry from high risk countries. Arrivals must have a recent (48 hours) PCR test or self-isolate. Exceptions being made for people coming to help after the earthquake.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201122110254/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html

A, C:    Vaccination Plan:  First, it is planned to vaccinate employees and users of homes for the elderly (and other institutions for the provision of accommodation in the social welfare system) and health workers, then (conditionally speaking, the second phase of vaccination) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases, and finally (conditionally speaking, the third phase) the entire population.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110040933/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uputa-priprema-za-cijepljenje-protiv-covid-19-884/884    Doses ordered:  Procurement is contracted with several manufacturers and the procedures are still ongoing.  Contracts with four manufacturers have already been concluded.  Under these contracts, we expect a total of 5,600,000 doses of vaccine by the end of 2021.  Considering that all * vaccines are administered in two doses with different intervals, the amount agreed so far is sufficient for vaccination of 2,800,000 inhabitants of the Republic of Croatia.  * except for Janssen vaccine for which there is a possibility of administering 1 dose  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110040933/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uputa-priprema-za-cijepljenje-protiv-covid-19-884/884    de facto capacity and evidence:  First doses of coronavirus vaccine arrive in Croatia  https://www.croatiaweek.com/first-doses-of-coronavirus-vaccine-arrive-in-croatia/    Croatian PM says COVID vaccines will be free  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110181420/https://www.croatiaweek.com/croatian-pm-says-covid-vaccines-will-be-free/

A, C:    Speaking at a cabinet meeting, Beros said that of the 20,603 vaccinated persons, 7,611 were doctors and other medical professionals (37%) and 11,569 (56%) were beneficiaries of old-age care homes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110181658/https://www.total-croatia-news.com/news/49477-large-share-of-population-to-be-vaccinated-by-mid-2021

A, C:    No policy changes.  See notes on 26 Dec for specific policies. The government announced that from midnight on 24 December until 12 January, Level 5 restrictions (the equivalent of full lockdown) will apply nationally, due to NPHET concerns at the rapid increase in COVID-19 case numbers.    Under normal level 5 restrictions, schools remain open, but the decision was made on 30th December to delay reopening schools for the new term. On the 6th January, it was decided to close all schools, including for students with special needs, for at least three weeks.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201230203846/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/education/schools-welcome-decision-to-close-until-january-11th-1.4447636  http://web.archive.org/web/20210107211029/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/11176-minister-foley-confirms-that-schools-will-remain-closed-to-students/

"Schools    Schools are currently closed for all students with remote learning in place.    Youthreach services will resume as scheduled.    The resumption of the Early Childhood Care and Education (ECCE) programme is delayed until 1 February.    Higher and adult education    Higher, further and adult education should remain primarily online."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210110221430/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/
No change recorded.

On 22 December the Taoiseach announced the introduction of level 5 restrictions (full lockdown) though with temporary relaxations for the Christmas period (24 to 26 December inclusive).     Retail stores were thus allowed to remain open.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201222133641/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/a1f21-ireland-placed-on-level-5-restrictions-of-the-plan-for-living-with-covid-19-with-a-number-of-specific-adjustments/

On 22 December the Irish Government extended its ban on flights and passenger ferry journeys from Great Britain until at least 31 December. This applies to people in Great Britain regardless of nationality. Ferry crossings from Great Britain to Ireland will continue for freight, including accompanied freight, but not passengers, although ferry journeys from Ireland to Great Britain are open to both freight and passengers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228200145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ireland/entry-requirements

A, C:    Iceland received the first doses of COVID-19 vaccine on December 28 and vaccination began on December 29. At the moment, Iceland is expecting to receive vaccine for at least 30,000 people before the end of March.  COVID-19 vaccination is optional and free of charge in Iceland. Vaccines are being administered according to priority groups defined by health authorities, though the Chief Epidemiologist may grant exceptions to that order. The first to be vaccinated were frontline healthcare workers and nursing home residents. According to the current vaccination schedule, the next priority groups are people over the age of 70, paramedics who transport COVID-19 patients, and some additional healthcare workers        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106190138/https://www.icelandreview.com/ask-ir/whats-the-status-of-covid-19-vaccination-in-iceland/      http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

"Throughout Italy, it is mandatory to wear a mask in public places indoors. The mask is also mandatory outdoors, except in cases where you are isolated from people who do not live togethet. In Lazio it is mandatory to wear a mask outdoors in any situation.    Those who are not required to wear masks:  - people who are carrying out sports activities  - children under the age of 6  - people with disabilities or conditions incompatible with the use of a mask; carers or care workers are not obliged to wear masks, in the event that the mask makes it impossible to interact between carers/care workers and persons with disabilities. The use of the mask is also recommended inside houses, in the presence of non-cohabiting people."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210116175732/http://www.italia.it/en/useful-info/covid-19-updates-information-for-tourists.html

No change in policy, all school levels remain closed except special needs schools and special needs classes in general education schools (I have decided to remain the level on "3" as all "normal" schools remain closed".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

No change in previous policy:    State and municipal institutions and bodies and state and municipal enterprises and the private sector will organise work and provide customer services remotely, except where relevant functions (work) have to be performed at the workplace, while ensuring conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment    Stores, including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres, marketplaces and other public points of sale will be closed except:    -stores (including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres), whose main business is the retail of food, veterinary, animal feed, pharmacy, optical goods and orthopedic technical devices;  -selling food in marketplaces and public points of sale;  -remote commerce (by internet or other means of communication), where goods are delivered to natural and legal persons or collected at collection points;  -funeral stores;  -outdoor trade in Christmas trees and other festive trees.    Stores that remain open will be required to:    ensure 15 sq. m. of retail space per visitor or serve only one visitor at a time and ensure other conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021
Restrictions remain in place (until 31st January)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124173336/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

There will be no indoor or outdoor commercial or non-commercial cultural, entertainment, sporting events, celebrations, fairs, festivals or other mass gatherings arranged in public locations of a certain duration at a scheduled time except:    -high-performance sporting events without spectators;  -funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except family and/or household members and persons providing funeral services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021
Restrictions remain in place (until 31st January)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124173336/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

It is allowed to be in public places in groups of no more than 2 persons or in groups of one family and/or one household.    It is prohibited:    -to have close contacts between members of more than one family and/or one household except:  emergencies, where it is necessary to provide assistance;  attending to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves;    -to hold private parties in public and private venues with the participation of more than one family and/or household.     Transport vehicles other than regular public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) or transport vehicles to commute to work may carry groups of no more than 2 persons or groups of members of one family and/or one household. When providing passenger transportation service for a fare by a passenger car on call and by a taxi passenger car, the driver of the vehicle will not be counted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

Protective face masks are mandatory in all public places (for all from the age of 6). Exceptions will apply in the following cases:     exercising individuals;  high-performance sports training;  during the provision of a service where a service cannot be provided when a customer is wearing a mask;  persons with disability who cannot wear a mask due to their health condition or where it can adversely affect their health condition. They are recommended to wear a face shield instead.  when outside populated areas (cities, towns, villages, single-homestead settlements and dacha (garden) settlements) and when there are no other people within the radius of 20 metres, except for family members;  children over the age of 6 who are educated under pre-school, pre-primary and primary education programmes will not be required to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) while in education establishments and/or their territories.  Face masks are mandatory in common areas.    It is recommended to wear a face mask at a private party, if held, or when socialising with members of other families /households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

A:    Lithuania started vaccinations against COVID-19 on 27th of December:    "Lithuania on Saturday started to vaccinate its medical workers against the coronavirus in a coordinated push by the European Union against the global pandemic.  Nijole Ramonaite, a nurse at Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos, was the first person in the country inoculated by the vaccine produced by Pfizer and BionTech.  Vaccination was launched in hospitals in Vilnius, Kaunas, Klaipeda, Siauliai and Panevezys simultaneously at 8:00 a.m. on Sunday."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154724/https://www.baltictimes.com/lithuania_starts_vaccinations_against_covid-19/    Regarding strategy:  Acting Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga said that medics and at-risk people in the country would be vaccinated from the coronavirus first. If a sufficient amount of vaccines is delivered to Lithuania, mass vaccination of the population could start in February or March, according to Veryga.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154743/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1296189/most-people-in-lithuania-to-receive-vaccines-by-mid-summer-says-president

On Tuesday, 29 December, The Cabinet of Ministers agreed on a “holiday curfew”, stipulating that all residents of Latvia from 30 December to 4 January, as well as on 8 and 9 January from 22.00 to 5.00, must stay at their place of residence. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. Consequently, sales and service outlets will be open from 6.00 to 21.00, so that employees can get from home to work and back without breaking the rules.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew

No specific measures implemented. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. The clarifications in the security measures for the holiday season approved by the Cabinet of Ministers do not restrict freedom of movement. Public transport will continue to run and people are encouraged to take the opportunity to spend time outdoors in nature.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew

In coordination with other EU Member States aiming to protect the public from the spread of the new coronavirus type in Latvia, the Cabinet of Ministers decided to suspend passenger traffic through airports, ports, as well as by bus from and to the United Kingdom from 21 December to 1 January 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111222314/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/passenger-services-and-united-kingdom-will-be-suspended-december-21

It is allowed to enter Latvia, provided that the guidelines developed by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) are being followed. When arriving from countries with a 14-day cumulative number of COVID-19 cases that is higher than 50 per 100,000 inhabitants, self-isolation must be observed for 10 days.  10-day self-isolation must be observed when entering Latvia from the countries listed in the “National COVID-19 morbidity rates” section of the SPKC website.  If a person is arriving from a “safe” country by transiting through an “unsafe country”, the person must observe self-isolation; in order to avoid self-isolation, a different return route must be chosen.  Self-isolation means staying in the place of self-isolation without exposing other persons to the risk of infection and without making direct contact with others (not receiving guests, not visiting anyone, not going to work or public places where many people may be present, except for going to the shop or getting to the place of residence or of self-isolation immediately after arriving in Latvia, using a mouth and nose covering).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207042737/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers

On January 7, the government adopted stricter regulations for all people entering the country to facilitate more epidemiologically safe movement and reduce the introduction of COVID-19 infection into the country. When entering Latvia both with passenger transport and a personal vehicle, one must present confirmation of a negative COVID-19 test result. The regulations will take effect on January 15.  One must undergo the test not earlier than 72 hours before boarding a carrier’s vehicle or before crossing the Latvian border individually, for example, by road. The condition on 10 days of self-isolation and other epidemiological safety instructions provided by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control of Latvia must be followed after entry from abroad with a high risk of infection remains unchanged.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210118233812/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/article/entering-latvia-will-be-possible-only-presenting-negative-covid-19-test-january-15

http://web.archive.org/web/20210106203752/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/support-entrepreneurs-and-employees    Income support is ongoing. You can apply for the allowance for November until 15 December, for December - until 15 January, and for January - until 15 February.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210106203752/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/support-entrepreneurs-and-employees

No change to previous measures. Broad economic relief and support available.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210106203752/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/support-entrepreneurs-and-employees
Coordinated public campaign still ongoing. Specific websites in place as well as information on social media among others:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207044619/https://covid19.gov.lv/en

From 19 December to 25 January, residents may get tested for Covid-19 without a doctor's referral if they have symptoms of the disease (signs of an acute respiratory infection, fever, olfactory disturbances, loss of taste, etc.).   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111225847/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19/about-covid-19/who-can-be-tested-covid-19-free

No evident policy change.  There is a voluntary contact tracing app available, however its not mandatory to use.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026225622/https://www.baltictimes.com/around_40_000_people_have_downloaded_latvia_s_covid-19_contact_tracing_app/
No change to previous policy.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111232931/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

A:    The first vaccination rooms in Latvia started operating on December 28, 2020. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Commission (EC) have approved the quality, safety and efficacy of the first two Covid-19 vaccines. These are the vaccine Comirnaty manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and the vaccine manufactured by Moderna.      The vaccine will first be given to medical staff working with Covid-19 patients and to the staff of the Emergency Medical Service (EMS). After that, other vaccines will be gradually delivered to Latvia. The first vaccines will be given to healthcare workers working with Covid-19 patients in hospitals and to the Emergency Medical Service.     It is planned that all other residents of Latvia will be able to be vaccinated starting from the second quarter of 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233236/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/vaccine  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233533/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/kad-vakcinas-bus-pieejamas-latvija

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020.     Restaurants will be open only for lunch. Access to restaurants will be limited solely to residents of Monaco and those who work in the country Distance of at least 1.5 metres between restaurant tables (instead of 1 metre).  Bars are closed (the State is funding strengthened provisions for total temporary layoff at a rate of 100%), except for hotel bars which can remain open until 10 pm for hotel residents.    Takeaway sales will be forbidden after 7 pm. Deliveries are permitted until 9 pm.      Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020. Curfew increased from 7 pm to 6 am. Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

As bars are closed with the further tightening of lockdown measures, the State is funding strengthened provisions for total temporary layoff at a rate of 100%, except for hotel bars which can remain open until 10 pm for hotel residents    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020. Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces    Children aged under five years and people who are exercising outdoors do not need to wear a mask. Those exercising should carry a mask in their pocket in case they need to put it on, however.  The wearing of masks in private spaces is strongly recommended, particularly when someone from outside the household or a vulnerable person is present.    Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

"Initially, vaccinations will be available to senior residents aged 75 or over, living either in care homes or in the community, who have received a letter from the Government inviting them to contact the COVID-19 Call Centre"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115170152/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/First-COVID-19-vaccination-in-Principality    In general:    Vaccines will become available gradually, and so the Prince’s Government has had to establish priorities to ensure that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:    -Elderly people living in care settings    -People aged over 75    -People aged 65–74    -People with underlying health conditions (obesity (BMI>30), particularly among younger people, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory disease, complex high blood pressure disorders, heart disease, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, recent history of cancer (within the last three years), solid organ transplant or haematopoietic stem cell transplant, Down’s syndrome, etc.)    -Healthcare workers, etcA    The vaccination campaign will therefore be rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165719/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/
No policy change

"Authorities in Moldova are maintaining international entry restrictions as of Dec. 7 to combat the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Authorities designate all countries with COVID-19 infection rates of over 100 per 100,000 population as "red" or high-risk locations. Most travelers from red locations are prohibited from entering Moldova, excluding Moldovan citizens and residents and their immediate family members, individuals with a work or study permit for Moldova, individuals in transit, and individuals traveling for urgent reasons. All permitted arrivals from red countries must self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival. As of Dec. 7, 63 countries are designated as red locations, including Canada, France, Germany, Romania, Russia, Spain, Ukraine, the UK, and the US; the full list can be found on the Ministry of Health website."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103132254/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/410051/moldova-covid-19-related-state-of-emergency-in-effect-as-of-dec-7-update-10

Until January 17th, primary and secondary schools, schools for secondary vocation education (MBO) and higher education institutions (universities and HBO) will deliver teaching online in order to reduce in-person contact. Childcare centres will also be closed. Primary schools and childcare centres will remain open for children whose parents work in critical sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

People should therefore continue to work from home, unless it is absolutely necessary that they go into work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Venues such as museums, theatres, amusement parks, zoos, casinos, saunas, indoor sporting venues, and establishments serving food and drink (including in hotels) will be closed throughout this period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

The government is also advising people to receive no more than 2 people aged 13 or over at home per day. There is an exception to this on 24, 25 and 26 December: then, up to 3 people can visit, excluding children under 13. Outside, the maximum group size is 2 people, including during the festive period.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

The government is also advising people to receive no more than 2 people aged 13 or over at home per day. Outside, the maximum group size is 2 people, including during the festive period.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Public transport is for essential travel only.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

From the government's page: "Stay at home as much as possible, including during the festive season."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Stay at home recommended, no traveling.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Do not book any foreign travel until mid-March at the earliest and do not travel abroad.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Extensive support packages in place for workers    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106121236/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-financiele-regelingen/overzicht-financiele-regelingen

Two of the temporary measures are the Temporary emergency scheme for job retention (NOW) and the Temporary self-employment income support and loan scheme (TOZO).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123175030/https://business.gov.nl/corona/overview/the-coronavirus-and-your-company/

Tozo3 and 4: Self-employed professionals can apply for Tozo, the temporary benefit to bridge the loss of income over the months October 2020 - July 2021 in the municipality where they live.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123175030/https://business.gov.nl/corona/overview/the-coronavirus-and-your-company/

Through government websites, social media, media/news outlets, etc. Downloadable pamphlets available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

If you have (mild) symptoms of COVID-19, make an appointment to get tested. People who do not have symptoms can only get tested if one or both of the following apply: Contact tracing has shown they have been in close contact with an infected person. They have received a notification from the CoronaMelder app following contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

CoronaMelder app put in place for tracing and contacting potentially infected peoples.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

Everyone aged 13 or over is required to wear a face mask for general use in the following situations: In buildings and covered spaces that are accessible to the public (in so far as these are open). Both customers and staff should wear a face mask in locations where contact-based professions are carried out. On public transport, in stations, on platforms and at bus and tram stops.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112025205/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/basic-rules-for-everyone

In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  Private gatherings and events  A maximum of five people may gather for private gatherings, such as a birthday in hired premises, outside their own some home. If there are more than five members of one household, then all members of the household are permitted to meet. (New)  There is a limit of ten people for indoor sporting events, cultural events, seminars, faith community gatherings, ceremonies, etc., in addition to a limit of 200 people where everyone in the audience is seated in fixed seating. Up to 50 people are permitted to attend funerals, even if the seating is not fixed. (New)  Regardless, the majority of these events will not comply with the current national guidelines and should therefore be postponed or cancelled.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/

The Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH/FHI) recommends that anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus is given the opportunity to be tested. Those that should get tested are:    Anyone showing symptoms of COVID-19, including anyone experiencing a sudden onset of symptoms of a respiratory tract infection.  Anyone who is a close contact to someone with confirmed COVID-19*.  Anyone arriving in Norway after having visited a red contry/area during the preceding 10-day period.  Anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus.  Other persons as assessed by a doctor.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113155943/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/testing-symptoms-and-close-contacts/

Students of grades I-III of primary schools return to school from 18 January. From the 28th of December:  Only essential stores will remain open. However, certain services (such as hairdressers) are allowed to operate under a strict hygiene regime).   Hotels will only be available to uniformed services, medics, patients of specialised hospitals, COS centers and staff hotels.   The ski slopes will close and sports infrastructure is only available to professional athletes.  The following pre-existing restrictions are extended:  Gyms, fitness clubs and aquaparks are closed.   Restaurants are closed, meals are only available for takeaway or delivery.   Hairdressing and beauty salons operate under sanitary conditions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia

Restrictions concerning public transport are extended from the 28th of December:  A maximum of 50% seating occupancy or 30% of all seating and standing positions with 50% of seating vacant in public transport vehicles.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia

"On 13 June 2020, Poland resumed border traffic within the framework of internal borders of the EU. It means that traveling and crossing the internal borders of the EU is permitted. Travelers have regained their right to freely enter, leave or transit through the territory of the Republic of Poland. Quarantine is not required. One should consider the restrictions which are in force in a neighbouring country while planning a trip abroad."    "Important!   From 28 December 2020 to 31 January 2021, compulsory quarantine will be imposed on persons who have crossed Poland’s border (both an external and an internal EU border) by plane, bus, or other means of collective transport - for 10 days, counting from the day following the day on which the border was crossed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120135849/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/questions-and-answers

he Polish Government has declared the whole of Poland a red zone from 24 October. As a result, strict sanitary rules and restrictions are in place.    Masks are compulsory in open public spaces across Poland, apart from parks, forests and National Parks. Children under 4 are not required to wear masks. If there are medical reasons why you cannot wear a mask, you must carry a doctor’s note with you explaining this. When outside, you should keep a 1.5 metre distance from others, unless you are a parent with a child under 13 or the carer of a disabled person.    You must also wear a mask at all times in enclosed spaces, on public transport, in taxis or in an open space where you are unable to maintain a 1.5 metre distance. Police and sanitary inspectors are entitled to issue you with an on-the-spot fine (approximately PLN500/£100) if you are found not to be wearing a mask when you should. Further prosecution could result in a fine of up to PLN 30,000 (£6,000) for failing to follow sanitary rules.              https://web.archive.org/web/20201101055552/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/poland/coronavirus

The Polish Vaccine roll out begins on the 30th of December. Medics, social workers, uniformed services, teachers and senior citizens are the first groups to get the jab (groups A and C). The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th (in mainland Portugal).  All educational establishments will remain open and continue to operate as they have been until now.  According to a document distributed during the briefing of the Head of Government, the measure applies to nurseries, schools and universities.  Note: In certain municipalities in the Azores schools remain fully closed (all levels) - reason why the code has remain unchanged despite these measures.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal http://web.archive.org/web/20210118163525/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-01-13/schools-to-remain-open-in-full-operation/57684
Rules depend on the zones based on transmission intensity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221101820/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/new-state-of-emergency-measures/
See latest Measures still in Place.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210112033409/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th in mainland Portugal.  "Establishments and services open to the public: essential goods stores, grocery stores,, supermarkets and hypermarkets may operate without time restrictions; health services, offices, dentists and pharmacies; restaurants and cafes may only operate on a take-away or home delivery basis; fairs and markets are only allowed to sell food products.  Establishments and services closed to the public: hairdressers / barber shops; gyms closed; museums, cultural and leisure spaces; prohibited events."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal  "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. (...) Shops and others commercial premises, with the exception of pharmacies, health centres and petrol stations, will close at 6pm on weekdays and at 5pm on weekends and public holidays. Restaurants can remain open until 10pm for takeaway and food delivery services only."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  Note: Since in Madeira, non-essential services are allowed to be open and restrictions apply to the opening schedules - meaning these are not fully closed - the T(argeted) flag was kept.
Only gathering of up to 6 people allowed so prevents public events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221101820/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/new-state-of-emergency-measures/

As per latest Nation measures in effect on 8th January 12, 2021  Events and celebrations limited to 5 people, unless from the same household.  Weddings and baptisms limited to 50 people  http://web.archive.org/web/20210110062642/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/medidas-covid19-ambito-nacional-v2/

Mainland Portugal: "The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th. There will be a general duty of home retreat. The movement and concentration of groups of more than 5 people is prohibited, in private or public spaces, unless they belong to the same household. (...) Public events are prohibited".  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal  Madeira: "Due to the epidemiological evolution in the Autonomous Region of Madeira, and according to Government Resolution No. 19/2021, the Regional Government of Madeira has adopted a set of new preventive measures, applicable with immediate effect as from the 13th of January, and which will remain in force until the 31st of this month. Gatherings of more than 5 persons are prohibited, unless from the same family unit, on the public way, or in any other public area (...)"  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111082652/http://www.visitmadeira.pt/en-gb/useful-info/corona-virus-%28covid-19%29/information-to-visitors-%28covid-19%29  Azores: On the Regional Government website, that includes the list of social and cultural events, the large majority of events for the month of January were either cancelled or will take place online, due to the COVID-19 restrictions currently in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210119141108/https://agendacores.pt/
Gatherings allowed for up to 6 people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221101820/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/new-state-of-emergency-measures/

State of Emergency in force until 15 January.   -	The use of face masks is mandatory.  -	Public transports are limited to 2/3 of the capacity.  -	In taxis / TVDE, the front seats must be used only by the driver, and passenger occupancy cannot exceed 2/3 of the remaining space.  -	Rent-a-Car - In vehicles with a capacity of 5 seats or less, they can be fully occupied if they belong to the same household. If the vehicle has a capacity for more than 5 seats, its capacity is limited to 2/3 of the total, unless they are part of the same household.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210112033409/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

Mainland Portugal : "The use of face masks is mandatory and public transports are limited to 2/3 of the capacity. In taxis / TVDE, the front seats must be used only by the driver, and passenger occupancy cannot exceed 2/3 of the remaining space."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal  Azores: Public transports are limited to 1/3 of the capacity.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118234233/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?aiovg_videos=prevencao-do-contagio-covid-19-em-transportes-particulares-e-publicos-dos-acores  Madeira: Public transports are limited to 1/3 of the capacity. "The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th.  There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to travel, except for authorized travel namely for acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities; health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people", among others.  "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. Until further notice, a curfew is in place: on weekdays from 7pm to 5am and  on weekends and public holidays from 6pm to 5am"  "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high. The island of São Miguel is classified as high risk. On this island, until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home as follows: on weekdays from 8pm to 5am and n weekends from 3pm to 5am."  Note: Since the measures in the Azores DO NOT apply to all 9 islands (currently only 1 has a curfew a T(argeted) flag has been selected.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-
Travel between municipalities is prohibited between 00:00 on December 31 and 05:00 on January 4 of 2021, except for health, urgent or other reasons specifically foreseen.   https://archive.vn/zWIxY
Prohibition of Travel between municipalities  no longer applies.
There is prohibition of movement between municipalities. There is also prohibition of circulation on public roads from 1 pm. On 9th and 10th January. https://archive.vn/JpX3v
Prohibition of Travel between municipalities  no longer applies.

Individuals should only travel between the islands (Madeira and the Azores) for essential purposes. If one has to travel from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago (Azores), a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before travelling and completing a passenger questionnaire before depart are required.     In mainland Portugal, there are no specific restrictions on mobility to cross land borders but the Government recommends only leaving home only for essential travel (T flag applied since the travel restrictions do not apply).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal
No change to policies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221142743/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/node/421189

Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland – and the United Kingdom;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  -Travel from other countries are prohibited.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210112033409/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to: - European Union countries; - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland – and the United Kingdom; - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay. It is not necessary to present the COVID-19 Test on these flights, unless the destinations are the archipelagos of Madeira or the Azores. - Only passengers on flights from the UK who are nationals or legally resident in Portugal are allowed to enter national territory.  United Kingdom (UK): - All passengers must present a negative test to COVID 19. - Upon arrival in the national territory, citizens who do not have proof of negative test results will be sent by the competent authorities to be carried out inside the airport. In this case, citizens will have to remain in isolation, under the terms defined by health authorities. - On flights from the UK to Madeira, passengers who are not tested negative should do so on arrival and between 5 and 7 days and should await the results in prophylactic isolation."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for families and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak and a recent extension until end-September 2021.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201105150539/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    The Government will support all families, irrespectively of their income, during the general lockdown (that started on Friday, January 15), by paying 10% of their electricity bills. The measure will cost between 20 and 25 million euros (monthly). For low income families, the reduction in the electricity bill might reach 40%.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118164726/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/01/12/governo-apoia-familias-com-cerca-de-10-da-fatura-da-luz/

"On mainland Portugal and in the autonomous regions of Madeira and the Azores, you must wear a face mask in all enclosed spaces. You should wear your face covering when you enter the building and keep it on until you leave.    On mainland Portugal and in the Azores, you must also wear a face mask outdoors where it is not possible to maintain a 2m social distance from people outside your family group. In Madeira and Porto Santo, the use of a face mask outdoors is mandatory, except when driving, exercising, while on the beach or walking the recommended routes in forest and mountain areas.    These measures apply to everyone over the age of 10 on mainland Portugal and in the Azores, and over the age of 5 in Madeira and Porto Santo."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

A,C:      Portugal begins vaccinating frontline health workers on 27 December. News reports and government immunisation dashboard shows that frontline workers and elderly are the two eligible groups currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111135939/https://www.publico.pt/2020/12/23/sociedade/noticia/portugal-recebe-70200-doses-vacina-covid-28-dezembro-1944109    https://archive.vn/m1Bk9

A, C:    Vaccination task force coordinator Francisco Ramos has set out Portugal’s ‘programme’. If all goes according to plan (meaning the Pfizer vaccination gets European Medicine Agency approval later this month), Phase One will start in January immunising:    People over the age of 50 with at least one of the following pathologies: cardiac insufficiency, heart disease, renal insufficiency or chronic respiratory disease requiring ventilation.  Residents of old people’s homes and those interned in professional continuous care facilities  Healthcare professionals directly involved in caring for the sick, Armed Forces personnel, security forces and all ‘essential service personnel’ (criteria still to be defined).    Code remains the same as this extra clause for clinically vulnerable has not yet been bought into effect    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111141448/https://www.portugalresident.com/portugals-vaccination-programme-opens-with-950000-getting-shots-between-january-and-february/

On January 15, the Ministry of Health announced that more than 106 thousand people in Portugal received the first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine.  The vaccination plan in the country started on December 27 in hospitals and targets health workers and those working in care homes (A)."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118155254/https://www.publico.pt/2021/01/15/sociedade/noticia/105-mil-pessoas-ja-vacinadas-covid19-portugal-1946497

A decision on reopening the schools in Romania will be taken on February 2, after a review of the country's coronavirus situation, prime minister Florin Citu said on Tuesday, January 19.   He also said that "if things remain as they are" when it comes to the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic in Romania, schools will reopen on February 8, under the conditions announced by president Klaus Iohannis.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123124020/https://www.romania-insider.com/decision-schools-reopening-early-february-2021

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours. The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.20) of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities.  Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp,  https://archive.fo/T7Aib, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf and https://archive.fo/un88p

On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).  According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020 of The National Committee for Emergency Situations, the list of countries of high epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on the persons arriving in Romania from them was approved.  Link: https://archive.fo/pUara and https://archive.fo/s1GX6

According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020 of The National Committee for Emergency Situations, the list of countries of high epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on the persons arriving in Romania from them was approved. The National Institute of Public Health published the lists of states with high epidemiological risk.  Link: https://archive.fo/pUara, https://archive.fo/s1GX6 and https://archive.fo/wip/QkpvU.

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, “Datelazi.ro” (Updated data) project was released pro-bon by Code for Romania in partnership with the Government of Romania through the Authority for the Digitalization of Romania, containing data and information provided by the Government of Romania.   Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/X428Q

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.2020) of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces, regardless the value of the cumulative incidence rate of cases in the last 14 days (as it previously of this decision was). The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. Also, the chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 announced that the National Vaccine Storage Center is ready to receive vaccines after the European Medicines Agency issues the conditional marketing authorization. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL and https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh

A:    The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population. On 27th of December, the first stage started with the first 10 000 doses of vaccines in all 10 infectious disease hospitals on the front lines in the fight against COVID-19.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL, https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh and https://archive.fo/wip/pnsuB

Second stage of the vaccination campaign started on 15th of January and is aimed at people over 65 age, people with chronic diseases (regardless of age) and key staff working in key areas. The coordinator of the National Committee for the Planning of COVID-19 Vaccination in Romania, announced how the appointments of people over 65 years of age and those with chronic diseases can be made. (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are used).  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/IzHsa and https://archive.fo/wip/qeZ7F

The winter break in Moscow schools has been extended until 17 January 2021; this is valid for colleges, extracurricular activities for children, and sport schools supervised by the City Government. Extension was recommended to private educational institutions. Sixth to 11th grades are to study remotely until the end of the second quarter of the 2020-21 school year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104082129/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/
No Policy Change http://web.archive.org/web/20210108222859/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

No policy change.    In Moscow, clubs, bars and other entertainment venues are closed from 11 pm to 6 am. Also, entertainment facilities for children are closed. These restrictions are valid until 15 January 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104100018/http://government.ru/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104082129/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/
No Policy Change http://web.archive.org/web/20210108222859/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

Russian authorities are progressively albeit tentatively reinstating restrictions amid a steep rise in daily infections and hospitalizationsthat started in September 2020. While still resisting a tough lockdown , the regions are extending and increasingly reinstating a limited number of restrictions: : self-isolation (81 regions out of 85), remote work (63), mass gatherings (74), entertainment and eating establishments (82), unaccompanied child mobility (40), non-emergency medical care (36); and online learning. https://web.archive.org/web/20210118234814/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No policy change.    In Moscow, cultural, exhibition, educational, entertainment and similar in-person public events are suspended till 15 January 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104100018/http://government.ru/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104082129/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

In Moscow, The requirement asking People aged 65+ must stay home until the end of November. Working pensioners are advised to take leave or switch to remote work. Free travel for Moscow residents aged 65+ who must stay at home is suspended. People with chronic diseases and pregnant women must also stay home. Has been extended to the 15th of January.  People in risk groups are kindly requested to refrain from seeing their relatives who live in separate households and to ask younger family members to do the shopping. If necessary, they are allowed to go to shops and pharmacies, take out the trash, and walk their pets, but only wearing masks and gloves. Taking walks is allowed.http://web.archive.org/web/20210108222859/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

C:    Vaccination against COVID-19 has started in Moscow. The City Government is regularly extending the groups of residents who can sign up for vaccination. Currently, these groups include:    Muscovites over 60 (they are at the highest risk of severe COVID-19 and complications);  People with chronic conditions who are required to stay at home during the pandemic;  College and university students aged 18 and older.    Also, people aged 18 and over who work in the following fields and organisations can get vaccinated. In the future, it will be available to all Moscow residents.    As this is not yet available across all of Russia, I have coded this as a 1 for group C elderly groups, until more evidence emerges that this is accessible country wide    http://web.archive.org/web/20210108222859/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

Classes in primary and secondary schools will be continued from 18 January according to the dynamics that took place in September. High school students will attend classes every other week (half a class in a shift), and elementary school students will go to school every other day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111194136/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166089/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111202631/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166116/government-adopts-recommendation-of-crisis-response-team-to-keep-current-measures.php
No changes recorded.

The Education Ministry said earlier that elementary and high schools would reopen using the same model for classes that was in place since September 1 which means that elementary school children in grades 1 to 4 will go to school every day in smaller groups while grades 5 to 8 will go to school every other day and online. High school students will either go to school one week and have online classes every other week or stay at home for online schooling to the end of the year. Classes will be 30 minutes long instead of the customary 45 and the school year will be five days longerr because of the coronavirus pandemic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210118234843/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/serbian-schools-start-second-semester-teachers-unhappy/
