A:     On 30 December 2020, Minister of Health Zlatibor Loncar stated in Novi Sad that the vaccination of health workers began today and that those working in infectious diseases clinics and emergency centres have already been vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102195559/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165717/vaccination-of-health-workers-begins.php

A, C:    State Secretary of the Ministry of Health Mirsad Djerlek announced: "We plan to vaccinate about 11,000 people by the end of the week, with half of the vaccines being allocated to health workers and half to gerontology centers and social welfare institutions".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111210924/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165825/vaccination-of-11000-people-planned-until-end-of-week.php

A, C:      The Prime Minister Ana Brnabic stated that that there will be enough vaccines available for all citizens who want to be vaccinated against coronavirus (agreements exist for 8 million doses for 4 million of inhabitants). The plan for mass immunisation will be adopted by the crisis response team during the week of 18-24 January 2021.  Brnabic expressed the expectation that the first vaccination point will be opened at the Belgrade Fair by the end of the week of 18-24 January, adding that from 11 January, citizens will be able to apply to the system through which they will be able to express their desire to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111212830/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166035/preconditions-for-beginning-of-mass-vaccination-provided.php    Two groups coded as insufficient evidence to warrant higher code

A, C:    No policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111194136/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166089/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.ph  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111204053/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/

A, C. No change recorded in groups.    Pfizer, Sputnik V vaccine.    "On January 16, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic said that the country expected to receive an additional 250,000 doses of Sputnik V vaccine on Tuesday. According to Vucic, Serbia would vaccinate 80 percent of its seven million population with vaccines developed by different pharmaceutical companies.  "As of today, 28 percent are in favor of receiving Pfizer vaccine, 40 percent have chosen Sputnik V, the others do not care which one [to choose]," Derlek said during a television appearance."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210119002717/https://sputniknews.com/world/202101181081797801-live-updates-global-coronavirus-death-toll-reaches-2-million-people/

Pfizer, Sputnik V, and Sinopharm are currently in use. Negotiations are in progress for the AstraZeneca vaccine.    On 19 January, mass vaccinations began at the Belgrade Fair, Brnabic reiterated that mass vaccination of Serbian citizens is starting today and to that purpose, the first big vaccination site is opened at the Belgrade Fair and at the Torlak Institute. She specified that the first ones to be vaccinated are members of the Ministry of the Interior, the Serbian Army and other security services.    The Secretary of State appealed to the citizens to apply for vaccination in as many numbers as possible, but also to adhere to the protection and distance measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220302/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166671/very-good-start-of-immunisation-in-serbia.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220013/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166467/mass-vaccination-at-18-points-starts-in-belgrade.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166398/mass-vaccination-in-serbia-starts-today.php

A:    On 26 December, the first person received a vaccine and roll-out out 4 additional hospitals was scheduled to begin 27 December. Four waves of vaccination are planned:  1. healthcare staff, employees of nursing homes, critical infrastructure;  2. people older than 65 years, people suffering from chronic diseases, clients of nursing homes;  3. marginalised groups, homeless people, asylum seekers, teachers;  4. everybody older than 18 years (voluntary principle).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102214442/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22562138/vaccines-have-arrived.html

A:    No policy changes, workers in health care / social services are eligible to sign-up for vaccination currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109223845/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=frontpage&Itemid=1  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109224013/https://korona.gov.sk/tlacove-spravy/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220424/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Update immunization policy is in place from 18 January – currently health care professionals and other workers in health care facilities are eligible + newly also old people in nursing homes. People from critical infrastructure will be moved to the list of replacements, meaning they will receive the vaccination only if there is unused vaccine or someone fails to attend.    In the second phase:  residents of senior's homes and people over 65, patients with serious diagnoses, such as diabetes, oncological diseases, auto-immune diseases, cardiovascular issues and other chronic diseases     In the third phase: people in communities with a high risk of fast coronavirus spread like teachers, people living in marginalised Roma communities, homeless people and asylum seekers    In the fourth phase: members of the general public older than 18     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118213749/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22574807/vaccination-strategy-to-change.html
No policy change

"On the basis of the opinion of the expert group for the containment and control of the COVID-19 epidemic, the Government decided to extend the closure of schools and kindergartens for seven days until 18 January 2021."  Source: https://archive.fo/fqtMv

No policy change. In Slovenia, distance learning is carried out in all primary, music and secondary schools and in faculties. Kindergartens have been working in a limited capacity.  https://archive.vn/508cI
No policy change

The Government issued the Ordinance on temporary suspension of the sale of goods and services to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia, which enters into force on 9 January 2021 and will apply until 15 January 2021.    To restrict the movement of people and contain and manage the COVID-19 epidemic, a new Ordinance on the temporary suspension of the sale of goods and services to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia is proposed, which temporarily prohibits the offering and sale of goods and services directly to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia with certain exceptions that are necessary to meet citizens’ basic needs or are important for ensuring safety and health.    Some businesses are closed while some remain open, including hairdressing services.    https://archive.vn/vWP8z
No policy change

Public passenger transport is carried out in a limited capacity. Considering that faculties, secondary and primary schools, and kindergartens are still closed, public passenger transport is carried out according to the school holiday timetable.    The recommendations of the National Institute of Public Health on mask wearing, hand disinfection, vehicle occupancy, and entering and exiting vehicles must be followed.     https://archive.vn/508cI

No policy change. Movement between municipalities is prohibited with certain exceptions for which adequate proof must be submitted.  https://archive.vn/508cI
No policy change

At midnight on Saturday, 9 January, an amendment to the ordinance on state border crossing will enter into force, which will introduce the option to prove that a person does not have COVID-19 with both rapid antigen tests and PCR tests. When entering the Republic of Slovenia, negative PCR tests are required in case of arrival from third countries, which must not be older than 48 hours. Rapid antigen tests are valid only if done in the EU or the Schengen Area.     Testing with rapid antigen tests at border crossings has been abolished on the external Schengen border. The five border crossings and the Jože Pucnik Airport that have been offering rapid tests will therefore no longer continue to do so.    Anyone who does not present this proof will have to go into quarantine, which can, however, be lifted if the person takes a test within five days of the decision being issued.     Finland is removed from the red list, which means that entry from this country is possible without quarantine or a negative test. There are no changes in the list of third countries.    https://archive.vn/vWP8z  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110170450/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-01-07-the-governments-priorities-are-citizens-health-and-safety-the-pupils-of-the-first-three-grades-of-primary-school-and-the-full-opening-of-kindergartens/

"The temporary regulations give principals a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs. There are opportunities for the principal to take action if the school is open or if the school is or has been closed.  The Swedish Public Health Agency has previously recommended that upper secondary schools partially close and switch to distance education from Monday 7 December 2020 until Wednesday 6 January 2021. The Swedish Public Health Agency has now decided that this recommendation will be extended and apply until 24 January 2021."  Note: Since principals have the authority to decide whether to close high-schools, depending on the regional situation, and this is only a recommendation - making it unlikely for upper-secondary schools to close countrywide - a Targeted flag has been selected.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221201801/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

The Swedish Public Health Agency has now decided that this recommendation will be extended and apply until 24 January 2021."    Note: Since principals have the authority to decide whether to close high-schools, depending on the regional situation, and this is only a recommendation - making it unlikely for upper-secondary schools to close countrywide - a Targeted flag has been selected. The ban on public events of over 8 people remains in effect. This applies to "competitions and exhibitions in sports and aviation; dance performances; fairground amusements and parades; markets and fairs, circus performances and other events not regarded as public gatherings."   In addition, "All activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should be closed immediately until 24 January. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153454/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

In addition to the measures mentioned in the previous note, on 10 January, a new covid-19 law came into force which enabled the government to restrict numbers in shops and businesses, and close public places such as shopping centres and gyms. It has not yet mandated such closures, but from 10 January, shops, shopping centers, gyms and bathhouses must calculate the number of visitors to allow for 10 sqm per visitor. In addition, the maximum limit of 8 participants will also apply to private events in party centres and club houses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112112903/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/butiker-gym-och-kopcentrum-maste-begransa-antalet-besokare/

Temporary shutdown of public buildings  All activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should remain closed until 7 February 2021. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

The ban on public gatherings of over 8 people remains in effect, meaning in practice that all public events have to be cancelled.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153454/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Public gatherings and events may have a maximum of 8 participants meaning that no public events are allowed. The only exception in place is for funerals, where a maximum of 20 participants is allowed.   "Public gatherings include: gatherings that constitute demonstrations or which are otherwise held for discussion, expression of opinion or providing information on public or private matters; lectures and speeches held for the purposes of teaching or for public or civic education; gatherings for religious practice; theatrical and cinema performances, concerts and other gatherings for the performance of artistic work, and other gatherings at which freedom of assembly is exercised.  Public events include: competitions and exhibitions in sports and aviation; dance performances; fairground amusements and parades; markets and fairs circus performances. other events not regarded as public gatherings. Schools, public transport, private events and visits to shops are excluded."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Until further notice, no more than eight people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than eight attendees.   If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend.    Hence coding is 2G per interpretation guidelines when C4=4    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

The ban on public gatherings of over 8 people remains in effect. The Public Health Agency has "strongly recommended" to also adhere to these requirements in private.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153454/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    In the words of home minister Mikael Damberg: "The recommendations from the agencies aren't some kind of tips for the public -- they should be followed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214162622/https://www.thelocal.se/20201211/sweden-to-send-mass-text-banging-home-christmas-covid-rules

No change, max 8 people in public and strict recommendation to also follow this in private: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108133122/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Whereas the 8-people limit was initially only for public gatherings, under the newly enacted covid-19 law, it also applies to private events in party centres and club houses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112112903/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/butiker-gym-och-kopcentrum-maste-begransa-antalet-besokare/

Until further notice, no more than eight people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than eight attendees.  If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change since last entry. The Public Health Agency recommends to limit the use of public transport as much as possible. "You should avoid traveling by public transport and other public transport where a seat reservation is not offered. In the first place, you should use other modes of transport, such as walking, cycling or driving your own car."  Its recommendations to public transport companies include: 1) run schedules in such a way as to reduce the risk of congestion; 2) limit the number of passengers per vehicle; 3) inform their passengers on how they can reduce the risk of spreading the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154139/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154249/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

Still coded as 1G to reflect the recommendations 1) to the public to limit the use of public transport as much as possible; 2) to public transport providers to alter their services in a way that limits the spread of the virus.     1: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108134004/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/    2: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108134206/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

For travel in Sweden, you should avoid crowds, rush hour traffic, public transport without booking a place, and avoid meeting new people other than those you normally hang out with. You should also be able to isolate yourself at your destination and get home in a way that does not increase the risk of infecting others if you should get symptoms of Covid-19.  Nationally, from 7 January, masks are recommended in public transport on weekdays between 7-9am and 4-6pm  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125010102/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/domestic-travel-and-public-transport

In addition to the general temporary entry ban for non-EU non-essential travellers, as of 22 December, an additional entry ban was introduced for travellers from the UK and Denmark. The entry ban from the UK is due to the spread and mutation of COVID-19 that have been reported there. The entry ban from Denmark is mainly to reduce the risk of congestion and the spread of the virus in shopping centres and restaurants in Skåne County.    Exempt from the entry ban are Swedish citizens, people transporting goods, and people living in Denmark and working across the border in Sweden.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201218171409/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/temporary-entry-ban-extended-until-31-march-2021-and-amended-due-to-brexit/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201230204915/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/ban-on-entry-into-sweden-from-the-united-kingdom-and-denmark/

The general temporary entry ban for non-EU non-essential travellers as well as travellers from the UK and Denmark remains in place.     As of 1 January 2021, people exempt from the ban and travelling from the UK are required to present a negative test result at the most 72 hours before arriving in Sweden.     This requirement does not apply to those transporting goods – who may therefore enter the country without presenting a negative test result. This is to avoid impeding the transport of essential goods, such as pharmaceuticals or medical equipment.    Nor does the requirement apply to Swedish citizens, who always have the right to enter Sweden. However, the recommendation of the Public Health Agency of Sweden still applies, i.e. that everyone who has been in the UK should get tested for COVID-19 immediately upon arrival to Sweden, remain at home and get tested again after five days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104160031/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/negative-covid-19-test-result-required-for-entry-into-sweden-from-uk/

"The Swedish government has announced that entry bans to Sweden from the UK and Denmark will be introduced, due to the new variant of the SARS-Cov-2 virus. The ban will take effect at midnight, the night before Tuesday 22 December. (...)   The ban mainly means that all persons except Swedish citizens traveling from the United Kingdom or Denmark will be expelled if they try to travel into Sweden. Exceptions will be possible for people who transport goods and the like. For Denmark, people who work or live in Sweden will also be exempt. People from both the United Kingdom and Denmark who are judged to have urgent family reasons will also be able to be exempted from the entry ban.  The entry ban applies until 21 January 2021 or until further notice."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108134639/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/visiting-sweden-during-the-covid-19-pandemic

Temporary entry ban to Sweden  The Swedish Government has decided to stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban will be in effect until March 31. This ban has been introduced to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, and to reduce the spread of Covid-19.   The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. Moreover, the ban does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125010813/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions
No change since last entry

Short-term lay-offs may currently be granted for a maximum of nine consecutive months. The Government will propose that this time limit be temporarily removed until 30 June 2021. In practice, this means that short-term lay-offs granted in 2020 can be extended by up to a further seven months, or until 30 June 2021 at the latest.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125013744/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/11/additional-crisis-measures-for-businesses/
No change since last entry

Measures include (i) additional expenditures on wage subsidies for short-term leave, increase in transfers to relevant agencies to deal with the coronavirus outbreak and its repercussions, temporary payment of sick leave (also for sole traders), loans to SMEs, more funding to the media, cultural and sports sectors and for education and training, temporary rent subsidies to vulnerable sectors, temporarily more generous unemployment benefits, expanded active labor market policies, expansion of education, initiatives for green jobs and summer jobs for young people, temporary reduction of employers’ social security contributions, increased testing for COVID-19, additional general grants to municipalities and regions, temporary grants to businesses based on their loss of turnover to cover their fixed costs, more funding to train health workers, supplementary housing allowances to families with children.    On December 10, the Government proposed to extend the state credit guarantee program for loans to companies until June 30, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125014308/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change since last entry

The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends that adults with symptoms of COVID-19 get tested to see if they have an ongoing infection. The same recommendation applies to children of school age and older, i.e., from about 6 years of age. Younger children of preschool age are primarily advised to stay at home if they are ill, without taking a test. It is the regions that decide which people to test, and there may be regional variations from the national recommendations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125020028/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/

In the next step, contact those who may have been exposed to infection. This is done either by the infected himself, in dialogue with a vector, or by a vector in the responsible region. Anyone contacted in a contagion is informed of what this means and what action may need to be taken. Each person receiving a positive test result (PCR test) gives rise to a new infection tracking.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125020700/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/

A, C:    The first vaccinations took place on 27 December. The Public Health Agency has recommended different phases for the vaccination, according to the need for protection of respective groups. Phase 2 is expected to start in February 2021.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161641/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/vaccinationerna-i-sverige-har-inletts/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162056/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/rekommendationer-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/

Dining establishments such as restaurants, patisseries, cafes, and cafeterias will no longer be open for in-person dining and will be offering delivery services between 10:00 and 20:00. There are screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry. A PCR test is required only for passengers with symptoms for COVID-19. Passengers arriving in Turkey will be required to complete an information form and will be checked for symptoms.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/GL55V

There are screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry. A PCR test is required only for passengers with symptoms for COVID-19. Passengers arriving in Turkey will be required to complete an information form and will be checked for symptoms.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/GL55V

Starting with 30th of December, all travelers who arrive in Turkey through air, land or sea will be asked to present a negative PCR test result document issued 72 ours prior to arrival. Those who fail to do so at the border gate or seaport will be quarantined in the address to where they are going. Travelers who arrived in Turkey from United Kingdom, Denmark or South Africa in the past 10 days will be asked to present a negative test result done within the past 72 hours, and also will be required to quarantine in the address to where they are going.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days.   Link: https://archive.fo/2qeZb

Ukraine government implements extended quarantine measures as announced on 9th December 2020. The enhanced measures will be in place from 00:00 on the 8th January 2021 until 00:00 on the 25th January 2021. These measures refer to the closing of all schools across Ukraine, the closing of most workplaces, and banning all public events. On 30 December, negotiations to purchase the vaccine from Sinovax were completed.  Vaccines are also expected via COVAX agreements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210116230731/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/moz-uklalo-dogovir-na-postavku-18-mln-doz-vakcini-proti-covid-19-kompanii-sinovak  https://web.archive.org/web/20210116230931/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-zakupovue-vakcini-proti-covid-19-za-vartistju-jaku-viznacheno-dlja-bilshosti-krain-svitu
School and university students are having academic holidays until January 11.   Links: https://archive.vn/pajju https://t.me/eduuz/3876

From 11 January, schools and universities are open across the country. The government requires schools and universities to provide health protection to students. Moreover, the government allows continuing online learning for those students who belong to risk groups and have chronic diseases.  Links: https://archive.vn/D52gP https://archive.vn/IgGjB https://archive.vn/9l68x
Currently, schools continue to operate in-person.   Link: https://archive.vn/5bc9e

No update on workplace closure was found at the beginning of January 2021.   The UK Embassy states that hotels, motels, and guest houses have reopened (but are subject to special health and safety rules) following the easing of restrictive measures. From 15 August, all shopping malls, clothing markets, restaurants, cafes, beauty salons, and larger shops, as well as gyms, swimming pools, private kindergartens, and education centers have reopened.  Link: https://archive.vn/hMl5w

The last policy on public events was announced on 13 December 2020. Accordingly, the government prohibited the mass celebration of New Year within schools, universities, companies, etc. However, gatherings in a group of fewer than 30 people are allowed to take place.   Links: https://archive.vn/zYBmd https://t.me/ssvuz/3991
According to the US Embassy website, large gatherings and major religious services have been officially discouraged.  Link: https://archive.vn/5bc9e
The last policy on gatherings was announced on 13 December 2020. Accordingly, gatherings are banned for more than 30 people in a group.   Link: https://archive.vn/zYBmd

No updates on public transport policy are found.  Currently, public transport is operating across the country according to the UK embassy website. Whereas the US Embassy website from Dec 29 says that public transportation is operating, with masks and proper social distancing measures.  Taxis should have plastic screens between the front and back seats. Links: https://archive.vn/hMl5w https://archive.vn/OP9Li
According to the US Embassy website, public transportation is operating. Masks are required in all forms of public transportation and taxis.  Link: https://archive.vn/5bc9e
No "stay at home" has been reported recently.
Train travel between regions is now operating. Internal air flights are also operating. No lockdown measures have been reported.   Links: https://archive.vn/hMl5w https://archive.vn/dmb6y
According to the US Embassy website, there are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.   Link: https://archive.vn/5bc9e

Uzbekistan has barred passengers from 8 countries (Denmark, Germany, Australia, Austria, Italy, the Netherlands, South Africa and the United Kingdom) from entering the country until January 10th. This policy was announced on December 22, I could not find information on when it was put in place.  source:  https://archive.fo/NMcmU

Uzbekistan suspended flights with Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Australia, the Netherlands, and South Africa from 21 December 2020 until January 10, 2021.  Link: https://archive.vn/2bXRj

Uzbekistan extends the ban on flights from Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Australia, the Netherlands, and South Africa until February 1. It should be noted that the government of Uzbekistan suspended flights with the abovementioned countries on 21 December 2020. Link: https://archive.vn/2bXRj https://archive.vn/RsCF1

The ban on flights from Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Australia, the Netherlands, and South Africa is effective until February 1. It should be noted that the government of Uzbekistan suspended flights with the abovementioned countries on 21 December 2020. However, Uzbekistan has recently resumed the flights to Dushanbe, Delhi, and Kazan.   Link: https://archive.vn/2bXRj https://archive.vn/RsCF1 https://archive.vn/LwxEV https://archive.vn/nYxgX https://archive.vn/0qwSZ

No evidence of income support for those who lost their jobs due to COVID-19 was found.   The President of Uzbekistan has recently stated that “We cannot allow people who lost their jobs due to the pandemic to become poor. Therefore, starting next year, a new system will be introduced that provides a threefold increase in the amount of temporary unemployment benefits".   Link: https://archive.vn/chLCL

There is no policy was found on debt and contract relief for households.  On the contrary, some regions of Uzbekistan are experiencing a lack of electricity and gas. Moreover, the central government has recently increased the rate/tariff on water and sewerage that has resulted in public discontent.  Links: https://archive.vn/eKp15 https://archive.vn/T1FBQ https://archive.vn/MqjsD
The government regularly updates on COVID-19 in 2 languages - UZ and RU - at the following website https://coronavirus.uz/uz.   Link: https://archive.vn/E2Jwl

The Government of Uzbekistan has established an official Telegram channel for information on COVID-19 related measures. The channel can be found at https://t.me/koronavirusinfouz. Also, the government has launched the hotline - 1003 - for medical questions related to COVID-19, with the information provided in Russian and Uzbek only.   Link: https://archive.vn/5bc9e
Individuals who are showing COVID-19 symptoms will undergo testing at government facilities.  Link: https://archive.vn/hMl5w

Those who have been in contact with a person who tests positive for COVID-19 will no longer be automatically quarantined but required to self-isolate for 14-days and subject to medical monitoring.  Link: https://archive.vn/hMl5w
You must wear a face mask while outside – you may be fined (up to approximately £100) if you do not comply with this regulation.  Link: https://archive.vn/hMl5w

The government is planning to purchase 2 mln doses of the COVID-19 vaccine. Those vaccines are primarily intended for people over 65, as well as medical workers, school teachers, and kindergarten teachers.  Link: https://archive.vn/ZV4La

Currently, the government has not officially announced its vaccination policy. According to the Uzbekistan Ministry of Health, Uzbekistan is making preparations to receive 100 thousand doses of the Pfizer and BioNTech vaccines. Moreover, the government is actively working on certification of Russia's Sputnik V vaccine.   Links: https://archive.vn/5bc9e https://archive.vn/Lyi71 https://archive.vn/Zfn4F https://archive.vn/YWE0j
